Take Home Exercise 1

Published

January 16, 2023

Modified

January 19, 2023

1. OVERVIEW

This exercise focus on using Tableau Desktop to create multiple population pyramids for Singapore based on data updated to June 2022.

Population pyramid

definition? what insights can be derived?

usage to analysts? decision makers?

1.1 Instruction

  • Reveal the demographic structure of Singapore at the Planning Area level by using the Age-Sex Population Pyramid method.

  • Display nine (9) Population Pyramids, each representing a planning area in a single view.

2. PLOT MULTIPLE POPULATION PYRAMID with TABLEAU DESKTOP

There are four (4) main flows involved to plot multiple population pyramid.

  • acquire and upload data.

  • inspect and wrangle data.

  • plot multiple population pyramid.

  • organise plotted charts on dashboard.

2.1 Acquire & Upload Data

2.1.1 Acquire Data

This study will be based on demographic data set downloadable from Singstat.gov.sg.

  • Download “Singapore Residents by Planning Area Subzone, Age Group, Sex and Type of Dwelling, June 2022” in CSV format.
Highlights of the data set

  1. Data may not add up due to rounding.

  2. For June 2022, Planning Areas refer to areas demarcated in the Urban Redevelopment Authority’s Master Plan 2019.

  3. Data from 2003 onwards exclude residents who have been away from Singapore for a continuous period of 12 months or longer as at the reference period.

  4. Metadata :

    • PA = Planning Area

    • SZ = Subzone

    • AG = Age Group

    • Sex = Sex

    • TOD = Type of Dwelling

    • Pop = Resident Count

    • Time - Time / Period

2.1.2 Upload Data

Step-1 : Click “File” from the Tableau Desktop main menu and select “Open” from the drop-down options.

note : If the above screen is not your landed screen, click here

Fret not! If Figure 2.2 is your landed screen, from the bottom left corner, click “Data Source”. You will be directed to the homepage, then perform Step-1.

Step-2 : Select “respopagesextod2022” when prompted by an “Open” window.

2.2 Wrangle Data

2.2.1 Derive New Calculated Fields

Step-3 : Click on the inverted triangle icon under the “Sex” field, as highlighted in Figure 2.3.

Step-4 : Select “Create Calculated Field…” from the drop-down options (refers to Figure 2.4) to open an input panel, as shown in Figure 2.5.

Step-5 : To create “Male Population” measured field, first change the field title to “Male Population”. Next, input “IF [Sex] =”Males” THEN [Pop] END”, as shown in Figure 2.6.

Step-6 : Repeat Step-5 but with title as “Female Population”, and replace “Males” with “Females”.

2.3 Filter Top 9 Planning Area by Population

Step-7 : PA” field to place it within the “Rows” panel, as shown in Figure 2.7.

Step-8 : Double click “Pop” field from the table on the left. It will be automatically summed up within the “Rows” panel.

Step-9 : Right click on the space highlighted in red, above the population count column to sort the counts in “Sort descending” order. Refer to Figure 2.8.

Step-10 : Click the inverted triangle icon (next to “PA” at the “Rows” pane) and select “Filter” to open the “Filter [PA]” pane.

Next, change “10” to “9” for the “Top” value under the “Top” tab, as shown in Figure 2.9.

2.4 Plot Population Pyramid Trellis by Planning Area

Step-11 : Select “horizontal bars” from the “Show Me” chart options.

Step-12 : Drag “Gender” to “Color” under “Marks” pane. Next, drag the filtered “PA” to “Columns” and replace the “Rows” field with “Age Group”. Thereafter, place “Male Population” and “Female Population” fields to the “Columns”. Refers to Figure 2.11.

Step-13 : Right click the “Male Population” at the x-axis to select “Edit Axis…”.

Step-14 : Tick “Reversed” check box under “Scale” section, as shown in Figure 2.13.

Step-15 : Tick “Show mark label” via “Label” under “Marks” pane.

Step-16 : Right click on the y-axis to add colour to differentiate rows for visual references. Example can be referred to Figure below.

2.5 Create Chart to Reveal Gender Differences

Step-17 : Reproduce Figure 2.10.

Step-18 : Adjust the following fields accordingly :

  • filtered “PA” from “Rows” to “Columns”.

  • “SUM(Pop)” to the “Rows” pane.

  • “Gender” to “Color” under “Marks” pane.

Step-19 : Select “circle views” from the “Show Me” chart options and change the “Shape” to “Circle” under “Marks” pane.

Step-20 : Update the y-axis via :

“Edit Axis…” :

  • Change the y-axis title to “Population Count”.

  • Set the range to “Fixed” option.

  • Set 80,000 as the “Fixed start” value.

  • set 150,000 as the “Fixed end” value.

“Format” :

  • Set the “Shading” colour under “Default” to your preferred colour.

2.6 Create Dashboard for Visual Analytics

Step-21 : Set the dashboard’s Size to “Generic Desktop” and place the population pyramid trellis above and the gender differences chart below at the empty what space.

Step-22 - Right click the gender differences chart title to hide it.

Step-23 - Drag legend to place it below the gender differences chart. Set the “Arrange Items” to “Single Row”.

3. OUTPUT

4. DISCUSSION

Population Pyramid

Can only derive descriptive analysis by itself.

Combine with Other Chart

Add more context and more effective visual analysis.

500 words

- discuss patterns reveal by the analytical visualisation prepared
